group_1.textLeft: ......And so.
Lady Miyurin's phone came back safe and sound.

group_1.textRight: Thank goodness for that.

group_1.textLeft: I'm sorry to trouble you so much.
But the time paradox was somehow averted...!
What's more, what's more!
I feel like I was able to help Cornelia and Marius@get to know each other a little better,
if only as a result!

group_1.textRight: That is but the result of our own mistake.@I don't think we should be so proud of it...

group_1.textLeft: I knew about the ghostly disturbances that would@occur in that place,
yet I thoughtlessly put Lady Cornelia and her father@in danger regardless...

group_1.textRight: But you saved us, didn't you?@Before Lord Marius came racing in.

group_1.textLeft: Wha... Ah, that's true, but...

group_1.textRight: When I realized we were near the Temple of Venus,@I thought that things might get a little dangerous,
but I trusted that Amaryllis and the rest of you@would come to us if anything went wrong.

group_1.textLeft: Lady Cornelia...!

group_1.textRight: What did you talk about at the trading post...?

group_1.textLeft: I was just impersonating Lord Gaius and saying@the appropriate things!

group_1.textCenter: I will not force her to give it up.

group_1.textLeft: Saying things like that, I got the phone to fall into@Lady Cornelia's hands!

group_1.textRight: I'm so sorry to Lord Gaius.

group_1.textLeft: ...Oh, yeah, how did the real Lord Gaius react?
This cutie like impersonated the jeweler and@tended to him nearby, y'know.
Passed it off as a deal gone bad
while he was passed out from the ghost scare.

group_1.textRight: I observed what happened after that.
He was quite confused when he met the@real jeweler.
What... Are you saying that the deal is@already done?
And it wasn't canceled...?

group_1.textLeft: Yes... I was present, wasn't I?
I mean, you yourself were also at the trading post@just now, Lord Gaius, weren't you...?

group_1.textRight: ...It feels as if...
...I have no recollection of it.
By all means I should have been tended to by you@on the side of the road just now.

group_1.textLeft: Huh... What are you talking about?

group_1.textRight: Did another me talk to you at the trading post@on their own...?
Do you think this is the work of a mischievous@ghost...?
Everyone will think everything that happened@yesterday was the ghost's fault.
So, that helped a lot...

group_1.textLeft: We did something bad.

group_1.textRight: However, he was rather happy
that he brought back a great story to tell@his uncle Pliny.
If it's just a ghost story being passed on,@there's no risk for a time paradox.

group_1.textLeft: But, that guy...@He touched the phone at least once, right?
If he saw a moving smartphone even once,
wouldn't he want to get one later on after all...?
Oh, about thaaat...
The battery was already dead and the@power was off.
I thought maybe it had already turned@into a paperweight...

group_1.textRight: What...the battery died?!
How long has it been dead?

group_1.textLeft: Father said he didn't see it move either.
So maybe it had been in the same condition as@it is now, moments after we touched it.
...I think so too.
The jeweler and Cornelia's father...
They both thought
it was a small, highly polished mirror...

group_1.textRight: If you ask me,
it looks like a little mirror made of silver or tin@and glass laminated together.

group_1.textLeft: Which means, which means!
My phone is now just a mirror or a paperweight,
so if I lose it after this, no time paradox will occur!

group_1.textRight: Ancient Roman mirrors were not shaped like this.
The alloy used and the polishing technique alone
are over-engineered for this age.
I hope we can all be careful together so that a@misplacement accident does not happen again.
...Cornelia has a date with Marius today too, yeah?

group_1.textLeft: It's a three-person picnic with Lady Junia.
But before that, we have one important@meeting coming up...

group_1.textRight: You seem to be as busy as ever.

group_1.textLeft: Yeah. But we have to do our best!
